140. ANCHORING BIAS = fixating on initial impressions to make a diagnosis (Ex: burning throat pain diagnosed as acid reflux despite weight loss // women with episodic substernal chest pressure exacerbated by mental stress incorrectly dx with GERD instead of MI)
141. Availability bias = allowing recently seen or memorable cases to sway diagnosis (Ex: dyspnea diagnosed as influenza during peak influenza season instead of PE)
142. Confirmation bias = emphasizing evidence that supports presumed diagnosis and overlooking info that supports other diagnoses, related to anchoring bias (Ex: burning throat pain after eating spicy food diagnosed as acid reflux despite weight loss)
143. Framing bias = allowing diagnostic approach to be influenced by context and presentation of info (Ex: abdominal pain diagnosed as opioid withdrawal in patient described as drug seeking, correct diagnosis is bowel obstruction)
